1110168415145201664.text: This is absolutely insane. Hackers broke into an update server for laptop maker ASUS. The hackers then used it to push malware that looked like a legitimate ASUS update to thousands of computers. A golden supply chain attack leveraging update mechanisms https://motherboard.vice.com/en_us/article/pan9wn/hackers-hijacked-asus-software-updates-to-install-backdoors-on-thousands-of-computers …pic.twitter.com/AbRMhgteiq

1109612374976270341.text: Next week is probably the best possible week to experience Austin infosec. @BSidesAustin, @InfoSecConf, *and* @AustinHackers all happening in one week. You should absolutely come out.

1094946505704775680.text:
I am thrilled af to announce today is my 1st day at @capsule8 as VP of Product Strategy! 

I’m joining one of the best teams in the biz & am so looking forward to helping make security work beautifully *with* modern infra rather than fighting against it, towards true resilience

1094296201762025472.text: I recall you presenting on a new rev of Metasploit. You talked about the focus on exploit quality.  BrianV was like, "Quality?!" The notion of pride in reliable code, a constant focus for Brian with Windows, but applied to exploits was a remarkable joining of two worlds.

1093789855522410497.text: "We tested 9 different TLS implementations against cache attacks and seven were found to be vulnerable: OpenSSL, Amazon s2n, MbedTLS, Apple CoreTLS, Mozilla NSS, WolfSSL, and GnuTLS. The cat is not dead yet, with two lives remaining thanks to @BearSSLnews  & Google's BoringSSL."https://twitter.com/ivanristic/status/1093787788850483200 …

1092573323899342848.text: Version 2.9.1 of #OWASP #Amass was released! Now #gremlin server can act as the graph used during the #DNS #enumeration. We used this feature with #CosmosDB, but are calling #osint #tinkerpop users to test all #graphdb systems (e.g. #awsNeptune & #neo4j)https://github.com/OWASP/Amass

1087479586441424896.text: I didn't realize there had been this many vulnerabilities in apt's verification layer. Earliest I found was 2009 - averaging about one per year for the past decade.https://gist.github.com/roycewilliams/cf7fce5777d47a8b22265515dba8d004 …

1087472967964114946.text: Domains can also switch hands.  Intentionally or not. TLS doesn’t prevent the new owner from serving malicious payloads. Still over TLS.  At the end, we all agree that we need signatures + downgrade protection + TLS.

1107714328415879168.text: PSA for Go library developers. PLEASE do not put code into init() that touches the operating system (reading files or otherwise), it makes your library toxic for many use cases. Also, don't register CLI flags there, thanks =)

1096061500903481346.text:
A particular software vendor insists on using plain HTTP for online updates. Fortunately, they have a bug bounty. It paid me $1,426.62 for vulnerabilities that would have been much harder to exploit over TLS... so I donated it all to LetsEncrypt =) 

Full details once patched.pic.twitter.com/GUSrWTqkLf

1092886672671420416.text: The last week of March in Austin is looking epic for information security. BSides Austin (https://bsidesaustin.com/ ) kicks it off on the 28th, followed by InfoSecSouthwest (https://infosecsouthwest.com/ ) that weekend. If you plan to make either event, drop me a line!

1087593706444730369.text: It is 2019 and smart folks are dropping Apache 0-day because reproducing fuzz cases is hard for the maintainers: https://github.com/hannob/apache-uaf/blob/master/README.md … (via @hanno)

1087468447284584449.text: Lots of examples where software updaters get it wrong and TLS validation would have prevented or complicated exploitation: https://www.debian.org/security/2014/dsa-3025 … & all of these:https://github.com/infobyte/evilgrade/tree/master/modules/ …

1087466606354223104.text: Demand TLS for software updates. Leaking information on which package is updating enables automated exploitation and often downgrade attacks. Updaters can be vulnerable, but difficult to exploit if TLS validation occurs on the connection. Example: https://justi.cz/security/2018/09/13/alpine-apk-rce.html …

1074746216569806854.text: The "Hacking for the Holidays" Humble Bundle includes a bunch of my favorite security books, definitely recommended:https://www.humblebundle.com/books/hacking-for-the-holidays-books …
